Notes: Numbers of species (and 95% confidence intervals) predicted in different coppice stages by the generalized linear models for butterflies (A), moths (C), red-listed moths (E), saproxylic beetles (G), and red-listed saproxylic beetles (I).

Notes: Letters above the bars show post-hoc comparisons (Tukey HSD method).

Title: The effect of coppicing on insect biodiversity. Small-scale mosaics of successional stages drive community turnover
Notes: (i) freshly cut coppice, which includes clearings in the first season after felling

Title: The effect of coppicing on insect biodiversity. Small-scale mosaics of successional stages drive community turnover
Notes: (ii) young coppice, representing the habitat ca. 3–7 years after cutting, where resprouting coppice stools (stumps) already create a shrub-layer

Title: The effect of coppicing on insect biodiversity. Small-scale mosaics of successional stages drive community turnover
Notes: (iii) mid-aged coppice, ca. 10–15 years after the last cutting, representing a coppice stage with high stem density in the shrub and sub-canopy layer and high canopy closure

Title: The effect of coppicing on insect biodiversity. Small-scale mosaics of successional stages drive community turnover
Notes: (iv) mature coppice, ca. 30–40 years old, representing closed, shady forests prior to cutting of the coppice part, where the stem density and woody undergrowth is less dense due to self-thinning, but canopy closure remains high
